title: Cycle Closing
statementHtml:
You are given an undirected, connected graph GG with nn nodes and mm edges. The graph does not contain self loops nor multiple edges.

In one operation, you do the following, in order:

Note that an edge added by some operation can only be used by future operations, because the edges are added at the end of printing all simple paths.

Make GG complete in at most 22 operations. Specifically, GG must contain every edge (u,v)(u,v) with u<vu<v exactly once.

Note: You are provided with the input files for the first 1010 tests of this problem, along with 22 checkers (one in C++, one in Python) to verify your output. The checkers assume you follow the input and output formats of the problem. You can download the zip file from the Contest Materials section.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1031≤t≤103). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (3≤n≤2003≤n≤200, n−1≤m≤n(n−1)/2n−1≤m≤n(n−1)/2) — the number of nodes and edges in GG, respectively.

Each of the next mm lines contains two integers uiui, vivi (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n, ui≠viui≠vi), representing the edge (ui,vi)(ui,vi). The graph is connected and does not contain self loops nor multiple edges.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 does not exceed 4⋅1044⋅104 over all testcases.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print the following.

In the first line, print the number of operations opop (0≤op≤20≤op≤2) you want to perform. For each operation:

  • in the first line, output the value of kk (1≤k≤n1≤k≤n) you choose in the operation;
  • in the second line, output the number ss (0≤s≤n⋅(n−1)20≤s≤n⋅(n−1)2) of simple paths you want to print;
  • in each of the following ss lines, print kk positive integers, representing the path vi,1↔vi,2↔…↔vi,kvi,1↔vi,2↔…↔vi,k.
noteHtml:
Here is the explanation for the first test case:

Output token(s)Explanation
22Number of operations to perform (=2=2).
33Operation 1.  Value of kk (k=3k=3, paths have length 22).
11Number ss of simple paths in this operation (s=1s=1).
2 1 32 1 3The only simple path printed; when the operation ends it adds the shortcut edge (2,3)(2,3).
44Operation 2.  k=4k=4 (path length 33).
22Two simple paths will be printed in this operation (s=2s=2).
4 1 2 34 1 2 3First path; after the operation it inserts edge (3,4)(3,4).
4 1 3 24 1 3 2Second path; after the operation it inserts edge (2,4)(2,4). Note that the printing 4 3 1 24 3 1 2 would not be valid because it uses edge (3,4)(3,4), which does not exist until after both paths of this operation are processed.
